content: After reading all the messages i decided to remove huge f,b,n constraints.
Pretty clear. It is definitely doable in all three modes. I'm curious to see how it should behave for n = 1 (should it print 1 or 1-1?). Also, add a test for when f and b are equal.

Good Statement.
But for my understanding, the best game mode is Fastest. For Reverse, not bad. For Shortest, emm...
Are series of Fizz compacted too?

Sure. I updated statement and test cases.
EDIT: After implementing  solution i realized that it took more than 15 minutes to cover this case. I'm not the best programmer, but i guess for short 15-minute clash covering this corner case will take too much effort.
If n=1 it should print "1".  Updated the descirption (it mentioned only ranges before, without single numbers)

Alright so I solved it and my main concern is that you shouldn't need to optimize your code for a clash of code.

With n exceeding the 100 millions, you have to rethink your way of solving it and that's a huge nono for me. Clashes are supposed to be short and simple. Puzzles require optimization. Do not mix them up.

With optimization, you completely ruin the fun of code golfing (since your options are very limited) and make reverse mode even harder. It's gonna be very frustrating and I'm sure most of the players will never get 100% on this clash.

If there was another clash mode for optimization (like a code golf but your score is evaluated on the performances), this would fit perfectly but right now I don't think this constraint on n should be this big.

Tried it out and ( with JS at least ) there was no optmization needed at all.
The algorithm I used had linear runtime at was a usual approach for this kind of "problem".

With python, a simple for loop (from 1 to n) doesn't pass the 'Big Value' test (process timed out) so it's definitely an issue. Setting the limit for n to 10**6 instead of 10**8 would solve everything.
Huge n constraint added exactly to exclude simple 1..n loop solutions. Finding alternative solution will not be that long.

Honestly I kinda hate having to optimize my code in a clash of code. Clashes are all about implementing a working solution fast, and it's a completely different way of thinking if there are size constraints.

I understand your point: being able to solve this with a simple for loop would make this clash a bit too easy for fastest mode (even though it's still harder than most of the clashes). But optimization shouldn't be a necessity for shortest and reverse.
I have some problems with validator so i 'll update it bit later
